verse: When the enemies of the people of Judah and Benjamin heard that the returned ·captives [exiles] were building a Temple for the Lord, the God of Israel,

they came to Zerubbabel [a descendant of David; 1 Chr. 3:19] and the ·leaders of the families [heads of the fathers]. The enemies said, “Let us help you build, because we are like you and ·want to worship [seek] your God. We have been offering sacrifices to him since the time of Esarhaddon king of Assyria [680–669 bc], who brought us here.”

But Zerubbabel, Jeshua [3:2], and the ·leaders [heads of the fathers] of Israel answered, “You will ·not help us build [have no part in building] a ·Temple [house] to our God. We will build it ·ourselves [alone] for the Lord, the God of Israel, as King Cyrus, the king of Persia, commanded us to do [1:2–4].”
Then the people around them tried to discourage the people of Judah by making them afraid to build.

Their enemies ·hired others [bribed officials] to ·delay [frustrate] the building plans ·during [throughout] the time Cyrus was king of Persia. And it continued to the time Darius was king of Persia [522–486 bc].
When ·Xerxes [Ahasuerus; ruled 486–465 bc; Esth. 1:1] first became king, those enemies ·wrote [filed; lodged] a ·letter [accusation] against the people of Judah and Jerusalem.
When Artaxerxes [ruled about 465–425 B.C.] became king of Persia, Bishlam, Mithredath, Tabeel, and those with them wrote a letter to Artaxerxes. It was written in the Aramaic language and translated.
Rehum the ·governor [commander] and Shimshai the governor’s ·secretary [scribe] and those with them wrote a letter against Jerusalem to Artaxerxes the king. It said:
(This is a copy of the letter they sent to Artaxerxes.)

As soon as a copy of the ·letter [document] that King Artaxerxes sent was read to Rehum and Shimshai the ·secretary [scribe] and ·the others [their colleagues], they went to the Jews in Jerusalem and ·forced them [or compelled them by force of arms] to stop building.
So the work on the ·Temple [house] of God in Jerusalem ·stopped [came to a standstill] until the second year Darius was king of Persia.
